raw_data.question:
A 43-year-old woman presents with several weeks of episodic headache, sweating, and tachycardia. Her blood pressure is 185/105 mm Hg; review of her records reveals it was 125/80 mm Hg 1 year ago. CT of her abdomen is shown in the image.
What other condition is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
explaination: The correct answer is D. 69% chose this. The abdominal CT demonstrates a pheochromocytoma anterior to the left kidney. Pheochromocytoma is a generally benign tumor derived from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla that can produce catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine). Pheochromocytoma may be part of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type IIa syndrome or MEN type IIb syndrome. MEN IIa, or Sipple's syndrome, includes pheochromocytoma, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, and hyperparathyroidism due to hyperplasia or tumor. MEN type IIb syndrome includes pheochromocytoma, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, and multiple mucocutaneous neuromas or ganglioneuromas. Both syndromes are linked to the ret oncogene.

A is not correct. 8% chose this. Gastrinoma is a frequently malignant tumor derived from gastrin-producing cells in the pancreas. It typically causes hypergastrinemia, and is associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (a triad of marked gastric hypersecretion of hydrochloric acid, peptic ulcer disease, and hypergastrinemia). It may be seen in the MEN I syndrome.
B is not correct. 6% chose this. Glucagonoma is a rare α cell tumor in the pancreas that results in secondary diabetes mellitus. It may be seen in MEN I syndrome.

C is not correct. 9% chose this. Insulinoma is a β cell tumor of the pancreas, and is the most common islet cell tumor. It typically results in increased insulin secretion, and is associated with MEN type I (Wermer's syndrome).

E is not correct. 8% chose this. Neuroblastoma is a malignant, catecholamine-producing tumor originating in the adrenal medulla that develops in early childhood. It often presents as a large abdominal mass, and is an important cause of childhood hypertension.
raw_data.bottom_line: Bottom Line: Pheochromocytoma is an important reversible cause of hypertension in adults, and is characterized by episodic headache, sweating, tachycardia, and hypertension. It may be associated with both MEN IIa syndrome and MEN IIb syndrome.

raw_data.question: A 78-year-old man taking multiple medications presents to the clinic for continued surveillance after mechanical heart valve replacement. He has been taking warfarin after the valve replacement surgery, as prescribed. He denies any recent change in diet but notes that another doctor started him on a new antimicrobial. Coagulation studies show: Prothrombin time: 14 seconds Partial thromboplastin time: 36 seconds Bleeding time: 5 minutes International Normalized Ratio: 1.05 Which one of the following medications has the patient most likely recently begun taking?
explaination: The correct answer is B. 34% chose this. Griseofulvin can be used to treat superficial fungal infections. It is a cytochrome P-450 (CYP450) inducer. Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits the synthesis and γ-carboxylation of the vitamin K-dependent clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. It is metabolized by the CYP450 system, primarily the CYP2C9 member. Note that the prothrombin time (PT), not the partial thromboplastin time, is used to follow warfarin levels. In this scenario, the INR is 1.05 which is subtherapeutic. This suggests inadequate anticoagulation possibly due to increased warfarin metabolism.
A is not correct. 30% chose this. Erythromycin is an extremely commonly prescribed macrolide antibiotic (two-pack) and a CYP450 antagonist, which
would cause increased levels of warfarin and prolonged PT/International Normalized Ratio.
C is not correct. 15% chose this Isoniazid is an antibiotic used in the treatment of tuberculosis. It is a CYP450 inhibitor and would be expected to increase the warfarin level in this patient.
D is not correct. 13% chose this. Ketoconazole is a commonly prescribed antifungal. It, and the rest of the "azoles," are CYP450 inhibitors.

E is not correct. 8% chose this. Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor used in HIV triple therapy. Protease inhibitors are very potent CYP450 inhibitors. In this patient, HIV is extremely unlikely, and protease inhibitors are not used as monotherapy. This is not the best answer choice.
raw_data.bottom_line: Bottom Line: Inducers of CYP450 enzymes cause increased metabolism of warfarin.

raw_data.question:
A 47-year-old man is diagnosed with a slow-growing tumor located in the right frontal lobe of his brain. The tumor is surgically excised and the diagnosis is conﬁrmed with hematoxylin-eosin staining, shown in the image.
Which of the following is the normal function of the neoplastic cells seen in this histologic image?

options.A: Myelination of the central nervous system and peripheral nervous system
options.B: Myelination of the central nervous system only
options.C: Myelination of the peripheral nervous system only
options.D: Phagocytosis in the central nervous system and peripheral nervous system
options.E: Phagocytosis in the central nervous system only
options.F: Phagocytosis in the peripheral nervous system only

explaination: The correct answer is B. 67% chose this. The classic histologic appearance of oligodendroglioma is "fried eggs" with perinuclear halos and "chicken wire" capillary patterning. Oligodendrogliomas are relatively benign tumors that are derived from oligodendrocytes. The tumors primarily affect the frontal lobes of adults, and have a tendency to calcify. Oligodendrocytes normally function to myelinate the central nervous system (CNS). Whereas one Schwann cell myelinates one peripheral nervous system axon, one oligodendrocyte myelinates multiple CNS neurons.

A is not correct. 5% chose this. Myelination in the central nervous system is the role of oligodendrocytes, whereas the peripheral nervous system is myelinated by Schwann cells. Tumors derived from Schwann cells include neurilemmomas and acoustic neuromas. Bilateral acoustic neuromas are frequently associated with neuroﬁbromatosis type 2.
C is not correct. 6% chose this. Oligodendrocytes are not found outside of the central nervous system.
D is not correct. 6% chose this. Microglia are the phagocytic cells of the central nervous system, and macrophages and monocytes are the cells involved in phagocytosis in the rest of the body.

E is not correct. 14% chose this. Microglia have small irregular nuclei with relatively little cytoplasm; they function as phagocytic cells in the central nervous system and do not cause the tumor in the image.
F is not correct. 2% chose this. Monocytes and macrophages do not typically function in the central nervous system and would not produce the tumor in the image.
raw_data.bottom_line: Bottom Line: Oligodendrocytes myelinate multiple CNS neurons and have a "fried egg" appearance on histology.

3. Tumor location: right frontal lobe of the brain.
4. Tumor growth rate: slow-growing.
5. Diagnostic method: surgical excision.
6. Diagnostic confirmation method: hematoxylin-eosin staining.

raw_data.question: A 28-year-old HIV-positive woman presents for prenatal care. She states that she is 17 weeks' pregnant, according to the date of her last menstrual period. She has not yet had any prenatal care. She is otherwise in good health.Which of the following drugs reduces the risk of transmission of HIV to the newborn?
explaination: The correct answer is D. 59% chose this. Zidovudine is a nucleoside analog that inhibits HIV reverse transcriptase, preventing the incorporation of the viral genome into host DNA. A 1994 randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial involving HIV-infected women at 14-34 weeks' gestation who had CD4+ counts >200/mm3, had no or minimal symptoms,and had not received antiretroviral treatment during their pregnancy demonstrated that of the 425 mothers who completed the trial, the treatment group had their vertical HIV transmission rate reduced by 70%.

A is not correct. 12% chose this. Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside HIV reverse transcriptase inhibitor that prevents the incorporation of the viral genome into host DNA. It has not been shown to decrease vertical transmission rates and in fact is generally not given to pregnant women because of its serious side effect proﬁle. Efavirenz is never used alone (it can be given as part of HAART) and is usually given as part of a chronic treatment rather than as prophylaxis.
B is not correct. 16% chose this. Indinavir is a viral protease inhibitor that inhibits the assembly of new virus particles.
C is not correct. 13% chose this. Marviroc is an entry inhibitor that is a CCR5 receptor antagonist. This prevents the HIV virus from entering host cells.
raw_data.bottom_line: Bottom Line:Zidovudine is a nucleoside analog that inhibits HIV reverse transcriptase, preventing the incorporation of the viral genome into host DNA. It is frequently used for general prophylaxis and during pregnancy to reduce the risk of fetal transmission of HIV.

That's commendable that you are adhering to your medication schedule. The combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) is indeed the standard of care for preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV during pregnancy. This treatment can reduce the viral load in your blood to undetectable levels, which significantly decreases the chance of passing HIV to your baby.

To provide more specific advice, I would need a few more details:
1. What are the names of the medications you're taking?

history.doctor:
Great, that's a combination of drugs commonly used to manage HIV during pregnancy. Zidovudine and Lamivudine are both nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) while Lopinavir boosted with Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor. This regimen can effectively suppress the virus.

Another critical aspect in preventing transmission is the baby's exposure to the virus during delivery. 
2. Have you discussed your birthing plan with your obstetrician?
history.patient: Yes, I have discussed my birthing plan with my obstetrician. We are considering all options and will choose the safest one for both me and the baby.

history.doctor:
That's reassuring. In most cases, if your viral load is well-controlled, a vaginal delivery can be safe. However, in certain situations where the viral load isn't suppressed or there are other obstetric complications, a scheduled cesarean section might be recommended to further reduce the risk of transmission.

3. How has your viral load been responding to the treatment?
history.patient: My viral load has been responding well to the treatment; it's currently undetectable.

history.doctor:
That's excellent news! An undetectable viral load means the risk of transmitting HIV to your baby during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding is extremely low. It's less than 1% with effective treatment and careful management.

4. Are you planning on breastfeeding your baby?
history.patient: No, I am not planning on breastfeeding my baby.

history.doctor:
That's understandable. Although the risk is significantly reduced with an undetectable viral load, avoiding breastfeeding further minimizes any potential transmission since HIV can be passed through breast milk.

Based on the information you've provided, it seems that your healthcare team is taking all the necessary steps to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV. Continue following your prescribed antiretroviral therapy and work closely with both your obstetrician and HIV specialist throughout your pregnancy and postpartum period for regular check-ups, monitoring your viral load, and making informed decisions about delivery and newborn care.

Remember to also discuss plans for giving your baby prophylactic medication after birth as an additional preventive measure against HIV transmission. Your healthcare providers will guide you through this process to ensure the best possible outcome for your baby.

In summary, maintaining a consistently undetectable viral load through effective treatment, planned birthing options, and avoiding breastfeeding are key strategies to minimize the risk of transmitting HIV to your baby. Keep up the excellent work with your adherence to treatment and close collaboration with your medical team. If you have any other concerns or questions during your pregnancy, please don't hesitate to reach out.
history.patient: Thank you for the detailed information. However, I would appreciate it if you could be more specific about the prophylactic medication for my baby after birth. What medication will be used, and how will it be administered? Additionally, could you provide more precise guidance on how often my viral load will be monitored during the remainder of my pregnancy? And lastly, are there any specific lifestyle changes or precautions I should take to further reduce the risk of transmission? Your advice is invaluable, and I want to ensure I'm doing everything possible for the health of my baby.

history.doctor:
Of course, I'm glad to provide you with more detailed information:

1. Prophylactic medication for your baby:
   After birth, your baby will usually be given a short course of antiretroviral medications as prophylaxis. This is typically a combination of drugs like Zidovudine (AZT) or Nevirapine, which are safe and effective in reducing the risk of HIV transmission from an exposed infant. The medication is usually started within 6 hours after birth and continued for 4-6 weeks. Your pediatrician or neonatologist will closely monitor your baby during this period.

2. Viral Load Monitoring During Pregnancy:
   Your viral load should be monitored frequently throughout your pregnancy, ideally every trimester and closer to delivery. This allows your healthcare team to ensure that your treatment is working effectively to keep the virus suppressed. In some cases, adjustments to your medication regimen may be needed based on your viral load response.

3. Lifestyle Changes and Precautions:
   - Maintain strict adherence to your prescribed antiretroviral therapy.
   - Attend all scheduled prenatal care appointments to monitor your health and the baby's development.
   - Avoid exposure to infections, especially those that can affect pregnant women more severely, as they might impact your immune system and overall health.
   - Practice safe sex with your partner if applicable, even though your viral load is undetectable, condoms can prevent other sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
   - Keep up good nutrition and hydration, and avoid smoking, alcohol, and recreational drugs, which can negatively affect both you and your baby's health.
   - Inform any medical professionals who treat you about your HIV status so they can take appropriate precautions.

Remember, open communication with your healthcare providers is crucial. They will guide you through each step of the process, ensuring the best possible outcome for you and your baby. If there are any changes in your condition or concerns arise, don't hesitate to discuss them with your doctor immediately.

A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after blood pressure measurements were
175/105 mm Hg and 185/110 mm Hg 1 and 3 weeks ago, respectively. She has well-controlled type 2 diabetes
mellitus. Her blood pressure now is 175/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities.
Antihypertensive therapy is started, but her blood pressure remains elevated at her next visit 3 weeks later. Laboratory
studies show increased plasma renin activity; the erythrocyte sedimentation rate and serum electrolytes are within the
reference ranges. Angiography shows a high-grade stenosis of the proximal right renal artery; the left renal artery
appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
raw_data.options: (A) Atherosclerosis (B) Congenital renal artery hypoplasia (C) Fibromuscular dysplasia (D) Takayasu arteritis (E) Temporal arteritis
raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: Based on the information provided, the most likely diagnosis is (A) atherosclerosis. Atherosclerosis is a condition in which the arteries become narrowed or blocked due to the accumulation of plaque, which is made up of fat, cholesterol, and other substances. This can cause high blood pressure, as well as other symptoms and complications. The findings on angiography, which show a high-grade stenosis of the proximal right renal artery, support this diagnosis. It is important for the patient to receive appropriate treatment for atherosclerosis in order to manage their symptoms and prevent further complications.

mg/dL, and his urine contained granular casts. Four weeks ago, his oliguria resolved, and his BUN and serum
creatinine concentrations returned to normal. Examination of his kidneys at autopsy is most likely to show which of
the following?
raw_data.options: (A) Acute inflammation (B) Fibrinous exudate (C) Fibrous scar (D) Granulation tissue (E) Normal kidney
raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: It is difficult to accurately answer this question without more information. Oliguric renal failure can be caused by a number of different conditions, and the specific findings on examination of the kidneys at autopsy would depend on the underlying cause. In general, however, the kidneys may show signs of damage or scarring if the individual had chronic kidney disease or if they experienced a severe episode of acute kidney injury. In some cases, the kidneys may appear normal if the individual's oliguria resolved and their renal function returned to normal before their death. It is also possible that the kidneys could show evidence of acute inflammation if the individual had an infection or other condition that affected their kidneys.

In a pregnant woman who is receiving an intravenous opioid, this could potentially lead to neonatal respiratory depression in the baby. This is particularly concerning in the context of labor and delivery, when the baby is already at risk of respiratory distress due to the physical stresses of being born. Therefore, the use of opioids in this situation should be carefully weighed against the potential risks.

raw_data.question:
A healthy 30-year-old woman participates in a study of the relationship between cardiovascular function and posture. Placed in a room with a comfortable temperature (72°F) and humidity (40%), she moves from a standing to a supine position. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely in the reflex control of this woman's cardiovascular
system?
raw_data.options: (A) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity, Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity, and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart increase (B) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity and Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity increase, while Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart decrease (C) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart increase, while Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity decrease (D) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity increase, while Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart decrease (E) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity decrease, while Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart increase (F) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart  decrease, while Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity increase (G) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity and Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity decrease, while Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart increase (H) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity, Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity, and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart decrease
raw_data.answer: (A) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity, Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity, and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart increase
raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: Based on the information provided, it is most likely that the reflex control of this woman's cardiovascular system will cause a decrease in the activity of the Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart, while the Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity increases. This is because when the body is in a supine position, gravity no longer has as strong of an effect on blood flow, allowing blood to pool in the veins and leading to a decrease in heart rate and blood pressure. The Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart are both part of the body's reflexive mechanism for regulating blood pressure, so their activity would decrease in response to the decreased blood pressure. Meanwhile, the Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity would increase due to the increased volume of blood in the veins, leading to increased stretch in the atrial walls and stimulating the receptors. The answer is therefore (F) Carotid Sinus Baroreceptor Activity and Vagal Efferent Activity to the Heart decrease, while Atrial Stretch Receptor Activity increase.

Also, readings taken after a few minutes in each position would be helpful to evaluate your body's ability to adapt. 

As for signs or symptoms to watch out for, pay close attention to:
1. Orthostatic hypotension: This is a significant drop in blood pressure when you stand up quickly, which might cause dizziness or fainting.
2. Tachycardia (rapid heart rate): If your heart beats much faster than normal when you change positions, especially without physical exertion.
3. Bradycardia (slow heart rate): A slower than usual heart rate that causes fatigue, light-headedness, or fainting.
4. Chest pain or discomfort: Any chest tightness, pressure, or pain could indicate an issue with your heart, although it's less likely related to positional changes.
5. Persistent shortness of breath: Difficulty breathing that doesn't resolve after a few minutes of rest or changes in position.

These symptoms are not common in healthy individuals but should be reported immediately if they occur as they may suggest an underlying cardiovascular condition. Continue with the study protocol and keep a log of any observations or feelings you have during these positional changes, even if they seem minor, so we can review them together.

raw_data.question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a 2-day history of bulging of his left eye. He says his eye hurts. He has no history of major medical illness or recent trauma to the area, and he receives no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows exophthalmos of the left eye. MRI of the brain shows a 2-cm mass involving the ocular muscles of the left eye. A biopsy specimen of the mass shows malignant cells, some of which have striations. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
raw_data.options: (A) Neuroblastoma (B) Pheochromocytoma (C) Retinoblastoma (D) Rhabdomyosarcoma (E) Thyroid cancer
raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: Based on the information provided, the most likely diagnosis is (D) rhabdomyosarcoma. This is a type of cancer that affects the soft tissues, including the muscles that control the movement of the eye. The presence of striations in the biopsy specimen, which are indicative of striated muscle tissue, further supports this diagnosis. Pheochromocytoma, neuroblastoma, and thyroid cancer are all types of cancer that can affect different parts of the body and are less likely to be the cause of the symptoms described in the question. Retinoblastoma is a type of cancer that affects the retina, which is a different part of the eye than the ocular muscles.

Based on the information you've provided, it seems that your son's bulging eye without redness, discharge, pain, or vision problems might be due to a condition called pediatric proptosis. This can sometimes occur spontaneously and may be related to an underlying benign tumor such as a capillary hemangioma or a dermoid cyst. However, it could also potentially be due to other serious conditions like orbital cellulitis or a congenital abnormality of the eye muscles or structures.

Given this, I would recommend scheduling an urgent ophthalmology consultation along with imaging studies (like an MRI or CT scan) to better evaluate the cause behind the proptosis. We need to ensure there isn't any pressure on the optic nerve which could lead to long-term vision issues if left untreated. In the meantime, please monitor your child closely for any changes in his symptoms and avoid applying pressure around the affected eye.

Please note that this is an initial assessment and a definitive diagnosis will require further examination by an ophthalmologist. It's crucial we proceed with the appropriate medical investigations promptly.

Based on the biopsy results revealing malignant cells with striations, it's likely that your son has a rare form of pediatric eye cancer known as rhabdomyosarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcomas are cancers that arise from muscle tissue and can occur in various parts of the body, including the orbit (the area around the eye).

This diagnosis will require a multidisciplinary approach to treatment involving pediatric oncologists, radiation oncologists, and possibly reconstructive surgeons if needed after tumor removal. The standard treatments for orbital rhabdomyosarcoma may include chemotherapy, surgery to remove the tumor, and/or radiation therapy, depending on the specific characteristics of the tumor, its size, location, and whether it has spread.

It's crucial to have a comprehensive discussion with your child's healthcare team about the most appropriate treatment plan and the potential short-term and long-term effects of these treatments on his vision and overall health. raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: Based on the laboratory values and description of the patient's symptoms, it is likely that the primary hematologic defect in this patient occurred in the megakaryocyte progenitor cells. These are the cells that give rise to megakaryocytes, which are responsible for producing platelets. The high hemoglobin and hematocrit levels, as well as the increased platelet count and the presence of occasional giant platelets on the peripheral blood smear, suggest that the patient may have a condition known as essential thrombocythemia. This is a type of blood cancer in which the bone marrow produces too many platelets, leading to an increased risk of blood clots. The leukocyte alkaline phosphatase levels and the presence of splenomegaly on physical examination also support this diagnosis. Treatment for essential thrombocythemia typically involves medications to reduce the production of platelets and to prevent blood clots. Therefore, the answer to the question is (D) megakaryocyte progenitor.

raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: The most appropriate management for a completely displaced fracture of the femoral neck in a 32-year-old woman would be operative reduction and internal fixation. This will provide the best chance of a successful recovery and allow the patient to regain full function of their hip. Bed rest, closed reduction and traction, and the use of a hip spica hinge brace are all less effective treatments for this type of fracture. raw_data.question: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of failure to thrive. He also has had loose, fatty, foul-smelling stools and a cough during the past 2 weeks. He is at the 30th percentile for height and 10th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Laboratory studies show steatorrhea and a sweat chloride concentration of 80 mmol/L. A chest x-ray shows hyperinflation. Sputum culture grows Haemophilus influenzae and Staphylococcus aureus. Secretion of which of the following substances is most likely to be decreased in this patient?
raw_data.options: (A) Bicarbonate (B) Gastric acid (C) Glucagon (D) Insulin (E) Intrinsic factor
raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: The most likely answer is (A) bicarbonate. Bicarbonate is a substance that is produced by the pancreas and helps to neutralize stomach acid in the small intestine, where it plays an important role in digestion. In individuals with cystic fibrosis (CF), the thick and sticky mucus that is characteristic of the disorder can obstruct the ducts of the pancreas, leading to a reduction in the secretion of bicarbonate and other digestive enzymes. This can result in steatorrhea, which is the presence of excessive amounts of fat in the stools, as well as malnutrition and failure to thrive.

CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 490/mm³, and plasma HIV viral load is 45,000 copies/mL. Results of other laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Test results for syphilis and hepatitis B and C are negative. The patient agrees to begin antiretroviral therapy. He asks what his long-term prognosis will be. With adherence to the medication regimen, this patient is at greatest risk of death from which of the following?
raw_data.options: (A) Cardiovascular disease (B) Chronic kidney disease (C) HIV-related malignancy (D) Non–HIV-related malignancy (E) Opportunistic infection
raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: It is difficult to predict the long-term prognosis for an individual with HIV infection, as it can vary greatly depending on a number of factors, including the person's age, overall health, and the effectiveness of their antiretroviral therapy. However, with proper treatment and adherence to their medication regimen, this patient's risk of developing AIDS and other serious complications, such as opportunistic infections, may be greatly reduced. It is important for this patient to continue to receive regular medical care and monitoring, and to take their medications as prescribed, in order to maintain their health and reduce their risk of complications. In general, individuals with HIV are at an increased risk of death from opportunistic infections, HIV-related malignancies, and other complications related to the immune system. The correct answer is therefore (E) Opportunistic infection.

raw_data.question: A 19-year-old man who is in the US Army is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after he sustained a knife wound to the right side of his chest during an altercation. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. On physical examination, the trachea appears to be shifted to the left. Pulmonary examination of the right chest is most likely to show which of the following findings?
raw_data.options: (A) Decreased Fremitus, dull Percussion, decreased breath sounds  (B) Decreased Fremitus, hyperresonant Percussion, decreased breath sounds  (C) Decreased Fremitus, hyperresonant Percussion, dull breath sounds  (D) Increased Fremitus, dull Percussion, bronchial breath sounds  (E) Increased Fremitus, dull Percussion, decreased breath sounds
raw_data.answer: (B) Decreased Fremitus, hyperresonant Percussion, decreased breath sounds

This is because the knife wound to the right side of the chest may have caused a pneumothorax (collapsed lung), which can result in decreased or absent breath sounds on the affected side. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) decreased Fremitus, dull Percussion, decreased breath sounds.

history.doctor:
Of course, I understand your concern. Here are some immediate steps you can take to manage your breathing difficulty and prevent further injury:

1. **Calm Breathing**: Focus on taking slow, deep breaths to minimize shortness of breath. Avoid rapid or shallow breathing as this can sometimes worsen feelings of breathlessness.

2. **Rest**: Limit your physical activity and try to remain calm and still. Exertion can increase the demand for oxygen and might exacerbate your symptoms.

3. **Positioning**: If it feels more comfortable, try sitting upright with your arms resting on a table or chair back. This position can sometimes help open up your chest and make breathing easier. However, avoid lying flat if it worsens your symptoms.

4. **No Smoking or Inhalation of Irritants**: Ensure that you're not exposed to smoke, strong fumes, or any irritants that could inflame your lungs or airways.

5. **Travel Position**: While traveling to the ER, sit in an upright position in the car, if possible. This may help alleviate any potential pressure on your chest and improve breathing.

6. **Monitoring Symptoms**: Keep a close eye on your symptoms. If your shortness of breath rapidly worsens, you develop severe chest pain, lose consciousness, or start coughing up blood, call emergency services immediately.

7. **Inform Your Companion**: If someone is accompanying you to the hospital, make sure they know about your condition and the need for urgent medical attention. They should be prepared to seek additional assistance if your symptoms change.

Remember, these are temporary measures to help manage your symptoms until you receive professional medical care at the emergency room. It's critical that you get there as soon as possible. Once at the ER, the medical team will provide the appropriate treatment based on their examination and diagnostic tests.

A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 12-hour history of chest pain. Physical examination shows
no abnormalities. Serum studies show an increased troponin I concentration. The diagnosis of myocardial infarction
is made. It is suspected that this patient's condition deteriorated as a result of ischemia-reperfusion injury. The
increased serum troponin I concentration in this patient most likely occurred as a result of which of the following
processes?
raw_data.options: (A) Increased enzyme secretion (B) Increased enzyme synthesis (C) Karyolysis (D) Lysis of the endoplasmic reticulum (E) Lysis of the plasma membrane (F) Mitochondrial swelling
raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: The increased serum troponin I concentration in this patient most likely occurred as a result of lysis of the plasma membrane. When the heart muscle is damaged, such as during a heart attack, the cells of the heart can undergo lysis, or destruction. This can cause the release of troponin and other proteins into the bloodstream, leading to an increased concentration of these proteins in the blood. Lysis of the plasma membrane, which is the outermost membrane surrounding a cell, is one possible mechanism for this release of proteins.

A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a long history of pain with menses. The pain occurs on the
first day of her 5-day menstrual period and lasts all day. She rates the pain as 10 on a 10-point scale. The most
appropriate initial pharmacotherapy to relieve this patient's pain has which of the following mechanisms of action?
raw_data.options: (A) Inhibition of estrogen synthesis (B) Inhibition of 11β-hydroxylase activity (C) Inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis (D) Stimulation of follicle-stimulating hormone synthesis (E) Stimulation of luteinizing hormone synthesis
raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: The most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy to relieve this patient's pain would have a mechanism of action that involves the inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis. Prostaglandins are chemicals involved in the inflammatory response and are thought to be a primary cause of menstrual pain. By reducing the production of prostaglandins, medications such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can help to alleviate the pain and discomfort associated with menstruation. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) Inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis.

history.doctor:

The severity and duration of the pain you've described are consistent with this diagnosis, especially since over-the-counter pain medications have not been very effective.

However, given the persistence and intensity of your pain despite trying conservative measures, I would recommend a more thorough examination to rule out other potential causes such as endometriosis or adenomyosis. This could include an ultrasound scan or laparoscopy if necessary.

For now, we can discuss further medical management options, such as prescription-strength nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), hormonal birth control methods to regulate your periods and alleviate pain, or even alternative therapies like acupuncture if you're open to them.

I want to ensure I understand all my options clearly so I can make informed decisions about my treatment. Thank you for your guidance.

history.doctor:
Of course, I'd be happy to provide you with more information on these treatment options.

Prescription-strength NSAIDs are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs that work by reducing inflammation and blocking the production of prostaglandins, which are chemicals that cause pain and contractions in your uterus during menstruation. Examples include Naproxen Sodium (brand name: Aleve) at prescription strength, or Diclofenac (Cataflam, Voltaren). These can often provide better pain relief than over-the-counter NSAIDs like ibuprofen because they are taken at a higher dose or have a longer duration of action.

Hormonal birth control methods such as combined oral contraceptives (birth control pills), the contraceptive patch, vaginal ring, or hormonal intrauterine devices (IUDs) can help regulate hormone levels and reduce menstrual cramps. By thinning the uterine lining and making periods lighter, they can alleviate the severity of dysmenorrhea. For example, brands like Yasmin, Yaz, or Ortho Tri-Cyclen contain estrogen and progestin, which can effectively manage menstrual pain for many women.

Regarding acupuncture, it's an alternative therapy that has been used to treat menstrual pain with some success. The practice involves inserting fine needles into specific points on the body to stimulate energy flow and promote healing. Some studies suggest that acupuncture may help by increasing blood flow and releasing natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body. However, results can vary among individuals, and multiple sessions might be needed before significant improvement is noticed. It's important to find a licensed and experienced acupuncturist who has worked with patients for menstrual pain management.

Please note that while these treatments can be effective for many women, there might be side effects or individual variations in response. We will discuss all the details, benefits, and potential risks associated with each option during your appointment so that you can make an informed decision about what's best for you.

raw_data.question: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for genetic counseling because of a family history of genetic disorders. The severity of the disease is directly related to the number of repeats, and the patient's mother has 19 triplet repeats on each HTT allele, which puts the patient at an increased risk for Huntington disease. Genetic testing can determine the number of repeats in the patient's HTT gene and help guide appropriate medical management. It is important for the patient to undergo genetic counseling to understand their risks and the potential implications of the test results.

raw_data.question:
A previously healthy 33-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by the Secret Service for stalking
the president of the USA for 2 months. She claims to be married to the president's twin brother and states that the
president just had his twin kidnapped to avoid competition. She speaks rapidly and is difficult to interrupt. Her
associations are often loose. She says, "I haven't slept for days, but I won't even try to sleep until my husband is
rescued. God has been instructing me to take over the White House. I can't wait to be reunited with my husband. I hear his voice telling me what to do." When asked about drug use, she says she uses only natural substances. She
refuses to permit blood or urine tests, saying, "I don't have time to wait for the results." Which of the following is the
most likely diagnosis?
raw_data.options: (A) Bipolar disorder, manic, with psychotic features (B) Brief psychotic disorder (C) Delusional disorder (D) Psychotic disorder due to general medical condition (E) Schizophrenia
raw_data.answer: (A) Bipolar disorder, manic, with psychotic features
raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: The most likely diagnosis for this patient is (A) Bipolar disorder, manic, with psychotic features. This disorder is characterized by episodes of mania or hypomania, during which a person may have exaggerated feelings of well-being, racing thoughts, and unusual behaviors, as well as episodes of depression. In this case, the patient's rapid speech, loose associations, and belief in a fictional relationship with the president's brother suggest that she is experiencing a manic episode with psychotic features. Additionally, her refusal to undergo blood or urine tests suggests that she may be resistant to treatment.

raw_data.question:
A 62-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis comes to the office because of a 2-week history of falling. She says
her legs "give out" once daily; she falls to the ground but does not hit her head. She took pyridostigmine until
2 weeks ago when she decided that it no longer worked. Respirations are 30/min. Examination shows a hypophonic
nasal voice and ptosis bilaterally. Muscle strength is 2/5 in all extremities. The patient is told that she is in imminent
danger of respiratory compromise and that she should be admitted to the hospital. She says she knows her breathing
could pose a problem, but she hates hospitals and does not want to undergo more tests or therapy. She asks if she
can have a prescription for her former medication and if she can go home. Which of the following is the most
appropriate next step in management?
raw_data.options: (A) Assessment of medical decision-making capacity (B) Electromyography and nerve conduction studies (C) Involuntary hospital admission (D) Oxygen therapy by nasal canula (E) Pulmonary function testing
raw_data.chatgpt_explaination: The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient would be an assessment of her medical decision-making capacity. Myasthenia gravis is a autoimmune disorder that affects the ability of the muscles to respond to nerve impulses, causing weakness and rapid fatigue. In severe cases, the weakness can affect the muscles involved in breathing, putting the patient at risk of respiratory compromise. In this case, the patient's symptoms suggest that she is at risk of respiratory failure and should be admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and treatment. However, the patient has expressed her reluctance to undergo further testing and treatment, and it is important to determine whether she has the capacity to make decisions about her own care. If she does not have the capacity to make decisions about her own care, involuntary hospital admission may be necessary to protect her from harm.

If a diagnosis of hypomania or bipolar disorder is confirmed, medications such as mood stabilizers (like lithium, valproic acid, or lamotrigine) might be considered initially to help regulate your mood and sleep patterns. However, these medications would only be prescribed by a psychiatrist after a detailed evaluation.

In terms of immediate lifestyle changes, maintaining a consistent sleep routine is crucial. Try to get at least 7-8 hours of sleep each night and avoid disruptions to your circadian rhythm, like staying up very late or napping excessively during the day. Regular physical exercise can also have a positive impact on mood regulation but should not be done too close to bedtime if it interferes with sleep.

Regarding psychotherapy, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) could be beneficial once your symptoms are under control. CBT helps identify and change negative thought patterns and behaviors that may contribute to mood swings. Additionally, Interpersonal and Social Rhythm Therapy (IPSRT) is specifically designed for individuals with bipolar disorder, focusing on establishing and maintaining regular daily routines which can help stabilize mood.

Please keep in mind that these are general recommendations based on the information you've provided, and a personalized treatment plan will be developed by your psychiatrist after a thorough assessment. raw_data.question: A 40-year-old female secretary comes to the office because of a 2-month history of fatigue, and generalized aching and weakness of the proximal muscles of all four extremities. The patient initially noticed the weakness only while she was getting in and out of her car, but during the past 2 weeks, the weakness has progressed, so that she now has difficulty combing her hair. Since the symptoms began, she also has had aching of the joints in her hands that has responded partially to ibuprofen. She was adopted and family history is unknown. She has two teenaged children who are well. She appears uncomfortable. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 68 kg(150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2 . Vital signs are temperature 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse 90/min, respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg. The patient is alert and fully oriented. Physical examination discloses cracking of the skin of both hands that involves the tips and lateral sides of several fingers. The muscles of the upper arms and legs are somewhat tender to pressure. Results of serum laboratory studies show a creatine kinase concentration of 600 U/L and a lactate dehydrogenase concentration of 800 U/L. Results of complete blood count are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

history.doctor:
Based on your symptoms, which include progressive muscle weakness over the past 2 months, particularly in your hands and with activities like combing your hair, joint pain that responds partially to ibuprofen, and no significant accompanying factors such as fever, weight loss, changes in sleep patterns or recent physical exertion, it seems like we need to consider several potential diagnoses.

Your symptoms could be related to a variety of conditions including inflammatory myopathy (like polymyositis), early signs of a connective tissue disorder affecting the muscles and joints, or even a vitamin deficiency such as Vitamin D or B12. However, given the absence of other systemic symptoms and family history of muscle diseases, we may also need to consider more common causes like fibromyalgia or chronic fatigue syndrome.

I would recommend scheduling some blood tests to check for muscle enzymes (CK levels), vitamin deficiencies, and possibly perform an ANA test to rule out autoimmune disorders. Additionally, a referral to a rheumatologist or neurologist might be necessary for further evaluation, including possible electromyography (EMG) if needed.

history.doctor:
Thank you for providing that additional information. Elevated creatine kinase (CK) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels are indicative of muscle damage or breakdown. With CK levels at 600 U/L and LDH at 800 U/L, it strongly suggests an inflammatory myopathy like polymyositis or dermatomyositis. These conditions involve inflammation and weakening of the muscles, which aligns with your symptoms.

However, to make a definitive diagnosis, we would need further tests such as an electromyography (EMG) and possibly a muscle biopsy, in addition to ANA and other autoantibody tests to rule out autoimmune causes. I would also recommend assessing your kidney function since high CK levels can sometimes cause kidney problems.

I will refer you to a rheumatologist or neurologist who specializes in these types of conditions for further evaluation and management. They will likely discuss a treatment plan that could include medications to reduce inflammation and suppress the immune system if necessary. Please bring along the results of your previous blood tests to your upcoming appointment.

history.doctor: That's good to know, though frequent cocaine use can often lead to such issues. Have you experienced any emotional or mental health changes?

history.patient: Yes, I've tried to quit several times. I've tried to just stop on my own, but I always end up relapsing because of how easy it is to get cocaine around here. I didn't like the hospital outpatient group I was part of; it just wasn't for me. But I did go to a Cocaine Anonymous meeting once and I liked that. I didn't have any severe withdrawal symptoms, but I felt really anxious and had strong cravings.

history.doctor:
That's helpful to know. Cravings and anxiety are common during cocaine withdrawal. It's essential to have a solid support system in place when trying to quit, like the Cocaine Anonymous meetings you mentioned. Given your current situation, I would recommend considering a more intensive treatment approach such as an inpatient rehabilitation center or structured outpatient program that can provide both psychological counseling and medical management for cravings and withdrawals.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to explore any underlying issues or triggers that led to your increased cocaine use and address them through therapy. Have you experienced any significant life stressors, changes, or traumatic events recently that could have contributed to your increased usage?
history.patient: No, I haven't experienced any significant life stressors, changes, or traumatic events recently that could have contributed to my increased usage.

history.doctor:
Thank you for sharing that. Based on your symptoms and the pattern of cocaine use, it seems like you are dealing with a substance use disorder. It's essential to seek professional help in managing this addiction, as the cycle of abuse can be challenging to break without proper support and treatment.

Given your current environment which makes quitting difficult, it might be necessary to consider a change of surroundings to reduce the risk of relapse. Also, ongoing therapy, whether cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or contingency management, could be effective strategies to address your cravings and help build healthier coping mechanisms.

I would also suggest discussing medication-assisted treatments with an addiction specialist, as there are certain medications that can assist in reducing cravings and easing withdrawal symptoms. It's crucial to approach your recovery holistically, encompassing physical, emotional, and social well-being.

Lastly, do you have any questions or concerns about taking these next steps towards recovery?
history.patient: Thank you for the advice, Doctor. However, I find the suggestions a bit broad and I'm looking for more specific guidance. Could you please provide me with a detailed plan or steps I should take next? For instance, how do I find a suitable inpatient rehabilitation center or structured outpatient program? And what specific type of therapy would you recommend for someone in my situation? Regarding medication-assisted treatments, could you mention any specific medications that are commonly used for cocaine addiction? I want to ensure I understand exactly what my options are and what actions I need to take to start my recovery journey.

history.doctor:
Of course, I'll provide more specific guidance for you. Here's a step-by-step plan:

1. **Finding Treatment Services**: 
   - **Inpatient Rehabilitation Centers**: You can start by contacting your primary care physician or insurance provider to get a list of in-network rehabilitation centers. Alternatively, the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) has a national helpline at 1-800-662-HELP (4357) that can help you find local treatment facilities.
   - **Structured Outpatient Programs**: Look for programs that offer intensive outpatient services or partial hospitalization programs (PHPs). These typically involve daily group therapy sessions, individual counseling, and medication management. Again, your doctor or insurance company can guide you to appropriate resources.

2. **Therapy Recommendations**:
   - **Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)**: This is often used to treat substance use disorders, as it helps identify negative thought patterns and behaviors and teaches skills to cope with cravings and triggers without resorting to drug use.
   - **Contingency Management (CM)**: This approach uses positive reinforcement, such as rewards, for abstaining from drug use, which can be particularly effective for stimulant addiction like cocaine.
   - **Motivational Interviewing (MI)**: A non-confrontational method that helps resolve ambivalence about quitting and enhances personal motivation to change.

3. **Medication-Assisted Treatments**: There are no FDA-approved medications specifically for treating cocaine addiction. However, some medications may be used off-label to manage withdrawal symptoms or reduce cravings. For example, modafinil and disulfiram have shown promise in some studies, but their use would need to be under the supervision of an addiction specialist due to potential side effects and limitations.

4. **Support Groups**: Continue attending Cocaine Anonymous (CA) meetings for peer support and accountability. It's a vital part of recovery to surround yourself with people who understand and encourage sobriety.

5. **Environmental Change**: Consider changing your living situation if possible to remove easy access to cocaine. Even temporary stays away from your current environment during early recovery could be beneficial.

6. **Personalized Treatment Plan**: Ultimately, it's best to consult with an addiction specialist who can tailor a treatment plan based on your unique needs. They will take into account factors such as the severity of your addiction, medical history, and personal preferences to create a comprehensive recovery strategy.

Remember, recovery is a process, and relapse is common. Patience, persistence, and a commitment to long-term treatment are key to overcoming addiction.

I'm willing to start looking into inpatient rehabilitation centers and structured outpatient programs as you suggested. I'll also consider the therapy options like CBT and contingency management. I understand that there are no specific medications for cocaine addiction, but I'm open to discussing off-label options with an addiction specialist. I'll continue with the Cocaine Anonymous meetings and think about changing my environment to support my recovery. raw_data.question: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician with his wife because of a 1-year history of excessive daytime sleepiness. He does not think the symptoms are problematic, but his wife is concerned because he sometimes falls asleep on the sofa early in the evening when guests are present. He also once fell asleep while driving at night and drove off the road, narrowly avoiding injury. His wife says that he has always snored loudly, and over the past year, he has had episodes of choking or gasping for breath while sleeping. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 105 kg (231 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2 . His pulse is 76/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 150/76 mm Hg. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

question: Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

history.patient: I've been experiencing excessive daytime sleepiness for the past year, and I've even fallen asleep while driving at night.
history.doctor: Hello, I'm your doctor. How can I help you today?
Thank you for reaching out. That sounds concerning. Let's start by asking some basic questions to understand your condition better. How many hours of sleep do you get each night on average?
history.patient: I usually get around 7 to 8 hours of sleep each night.

history.doctor: That's a standard amount of sleep for most adults. Do you snore or have pauses in your breathing while sleeping, which might suggest sleep apnea?

history.patient: Yes, my wife says that I have always snored loudly, and over the past year, I have had episodes of choking or gasping for breath while sleeping.

history.doctor: That could be indicative of sleep apnea, a condition that disrupts your sleep quality despite the adequate amount of sleep time. Let's move on to your daily routine. Do you consume caffeine or alcohol frequently, especially close to bedtime?
history.patient: No, I don't consume caffeine or alcohol frequently, and I especially avoid them close to bedtime.

history.doctor: That's good to know. Have you noticed any changes in your weight recently, or do you have a history of obesity?
history.memory: [有相关信息]: He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 105 kg (231 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2.

history.doctor: That places you in the category of obesity, which is a significant risk factor for sleep apnea. Additionally, have you experienced any other symptoms like morning headaches, difficulty concentrating during the day, or mood changes?
history.patient: No, I haven't experienced morning headaches, difficulty concentrating during the day, or mood changes.

history.doctor:
Alright, thank you for the information. Given your symptoms of excessive daytime sleepiness, loud snoring, choking or gasping episodes during sleep, and your obesity, it seems likely that you may have obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). However, to confirm this diagnosis, a sleep study would be necessary.

Do you have a history of high blood pressure or diabetes?
history.memory: [有相关信息]: His blood pressure is 150/76 mm Hg.
history.patient: His blood pressure is 150/76 mm Hg.

history.doctor: Your blood pressure is higher than the normal range, which can be another consequence of untreated sleep apnea. High blood pressure often coexists with sleep apnea due to disrupted sleep and oxygen levels. Regarding diabetes, do you have a history or any family history of this condition?
history.patient: No, I don't have a history of diabetes, and there is no family history of the condition either.

history.doctor:
That's good to know. Given your current symptoms and risk factors, I highly recommend a polysomnogram (sleep study) to diagnose sleep apnea definitively. This will monitor your brain waves, heart rate, breathing patterns, and oxygen levels while you sleep to see if there are any interruptions in your breathing that could be causing these symptoms.

In the meantime, maintaining a regular sleep schedule, avoiding lying on your back while sleeping, and trying to lose weight can help alleviate some of the symptoms. If OSA is confirmed, treatments like continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy or other breathing devices may be prescribed.

Let's discuss scheduling a referral for a sleep study and potential lifestyle changes that can improve your condition. Would you like to proceed with this plan?

I'll also try to maintain a regular sleep schedule, avoid lying on my back, and work on losing weight as you suggested. Let's discuss the next steps for the referral and any lifestyle changes I should start with. Thank you for your help.

For weight management, consider adopting a balanced diet and engaging in regular physical activity. You can consult with a dietician or nutritionist who can create a personalized meal plan to help with weight loss. Additionally, incorporating exercises that strengthen the muscles of the upper airway, such as tongue and throat exercises, may also be beneficial.

If your blood pressure remains high, we will need to monitor it closely, and if necessary, discuss medications to manage it effectively alongside lifestyle changes.

Lastly, please avoid driving or operating heavy machinery when you feel excessively sleepy until we have a better understanding and management of your condition. Your safety is our top priority. I'll follow up with more detailed instructions after we receive the results from the sleep study.

Keep up the positive attitude, and let's work together towards improving your sleep quality and overall health. Take care, and we'll be in touch soon with more information on your referral and next steps.

raw_data.question: A previously healthy 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of exercise-induced cough and nasal congestion. She plays field hockey and has noticed she coughs when running up and down the field. The cough is nonproductive and resolves with rest. She has not had chest pain or palpitations. She takes no medications and does not smoke. Her sister has asthma. The patient appears well. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 90% and an FEV1 of 90% of predicted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

history.patient: I've been experiencing a cough and nasal congestion when I exercise, especially while playing field hockey.
history.doctor: Hello, I'm your doctor. How can I help you today?
Thank you for sharing that. Can you tell me more about the cough and nasal congestion?
history.memory: [有相关信息]: A previously healthy 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of exercise-induced cough and nasal congestion. She plays field hockey and has noticed she coughs when running up and down the field. The cough is nonproductive and resolves with rest.
history.patient: Sure, the cough is exercise-induced and happens when I'm running up and down the field. It's nonproductive and it resolves with rest. The nasal congestion accompanies the cough when I'm exercising.

history.doctor: That's helpful. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms, and do they occur only during field hockey or with other physical activities as well?
history.memory: [有相关信息]: A previously healthy 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of exercise-induced cough and nasal congestion. She plays field hockey and has noticed she coughs when running up and down the field. The cough is nonproductive and resolves with rest.
history.patient: I've been having these symptoms for about 2 months now. They occur when I'm playing field hockey and also with other physical activities that involve running.

history.doctor: I see. Have you noticed any other symptoms, such as wheezing, chest tightness, shortness of breath, or a change in your peak exercise performance during this time?
history.memory: [有相关信息]: She plays field hockey and has noticed she coughs when running up and down the field. The cough is nonproductive and resolves with rest. She has not had chest pain or palpitations.
history.patient: No, I haven't noticed any wheezing, chest tightness, or shortness of breath. My peak exercise performance hasn't changed either; it's just the cough when running up and down the field and the nasal congestion that seem to be the issues.

history.doctor: Thank you for that clarification. Have you had any recent respiratory infections, allergies, or changes to your environment that might be contributing to these symptoms?
history.patient: No, I haven't had any recent respiratory infections or allergies, and there haven't been any changes to my environment either.

history.doctor:
Great. Given your symptoms and the absence of other respiratory issues, it seems likely that you might be experiencing exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB), which is a temporary narrowing of the airways during or after exercise. It can also sometimes present with nasal congestion. This condition is often mistaken for asthma but doesn't necessarily involve all the typical asthma symptoms.

To confirm this diagnosis, I would recommend you to an allergist or pulmonologist who may conduct a breathing test called spirometry before and after exercise to measure how well your lungs are functioning.

In the meantime, avoiding strenuous activities in very cold or dry air, using a scarf to cover your nose and mouth when exercising in such conditions, and possibly even taking a bronchodilator medication prior to exercise as advised by a specialist could help alleviate your symptoms.

Please let me know if you have any history of allergies or asthma in your family, or if you've ever been diagnosed with either of these conditions. Also, inform me if you feel better or worse after taking over-the-counter antihistamines or decongestants when you experience these symptoms. 

Lastly, ensure you stay hydrated and maintain a consistent warm-up routine before engaging in sports to see if that makes a difference. This information will further guide our diagnostic process.
history.memory: [有相关信息]：Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 90% and an FEV1 of 90% of predicted.
history.patient: Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 90% and an FEV1 of 90% of predicted. I've already seen a specialist and had the spirometry test done. There's no history of allergies or asthma in my family, and I've never been diagnosed with either condition. I've tried using a scarf to cover my nose and mouth, and I always make sure to stay hydrated and warm up properly before playing. I haven't used any over-the-counter antihistamines or decongestants, so I can't say if they make me feel better or worse.

history.doctor:
Thank you for providing the results of your spirometry test and the additional information. Your FEV1:FVC ratio is within normal limits, which generally rules out asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). However, since your symptoms are clearly exercise-induced and specific to strenuous activities, the diagnosis of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB) still remains a possibility despite the normal spirometry readings at rest.

Some individuals with EIB may have normal resting lung function tests but exhibit a decline in lung function after exercise. A more definitive diagnosis would involve a post-exercise spirometry where a significant drop in FEV1 (at least 10-15%) after physical activity would confirm EIB.

Given your condition and response to management strategies so far, I would recommend you discuss further with your specialist about possibly conducting a challenge test where you would inhale a bronchodilator before and after exercise to see if it improves your lung function.

In the meantime, continue with the precautions you've been taking such as exercising in appropriate conditions and maintaining hydration. It might also be worth considering using a bronchodilator medication prior to exercise under medical supervision, especially if your symptoms persist or worsen despite these measures.

Keep track of any changes in your symptoms and report them to your pulmonologist or allergist. This will help tailor your treatment plan accordingly.
history.patient: I appreciate your advice, doctor. I haven't tried using a bronchodilator before exercise, but it sounds like it could be helpful for my situation. I'm willing to discuss this option with my specialist and see if it improves my symptoms during exercise. I'll also keep monitoring my symptoms and report any changes to my healthcare provider. Thank you for your guidance.

history.doctor:
You're welcome. It's always important to work closely with your specialist for an accurate diagnosis and effective management of your symptoms. The bronchodilator challenge test can provide valuable information in your case, as it simulates the effect of medication during exercise and could confirm or rule out EIB definitively.

Remember that early detection and proper treatment are key to managing conditions like this, so don't hesitate to discuss any concerns you have with your pulmonologist. They will guide you through the process and determine the best course of action based on your response to the bronchodilator and other factors.

In addition to medical treatments, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, gradually increasing the intensity of your workouts, and possibly incorporating warm-up routines that include deep breathing exercises can also help reduce the likelihood and severity of your symptoms.

Keep up the good work with staying hydrated and taking precautions during exercise. I wish you the best with your follow-up appointments and hope to see improvement in your condition soon. If you have any further questions or developments arise, feel free to reach out anytime.
history.patient: Certainly, doctor. I'll make sure to discuss the bronchodilator challenge test with my specialist to get a clearer understanding of my condition. I'm committed to following through with the recommendations and will continue to take the necessary precautions during exercise. I'll also consider incorporating deep breathing exercises into my warm-up routine as you suggested. Thank you for your thorough explanation and support. If I have any further questions or if there's a change in my condition, I'll be sure to contact my healthcare provider.

history.doctor:
You're very welcome. It's great to see your proactive approach to managing your health. Your understanding and cooperation are crucial in effectively dealing with your symptoms. Always remember that open communication with your healthcare team is vital for optimal care.

Please do keep me updated on any progress or changes, and if you have any questions or concerns before your next appointment, don't hesitate to reach out. I am here to support you throughout the diagnostic and treatment process.

Wishing you all the best with your upcoming appointments and continued improvement in your health. Take care, stay safe, and maintain a balanced lifestyle to support your overall well-being.

However, it's also essential to rule out more serious conditions like breast cancer, particularly intraductal papillomas.

I would recommend scheduling an in-person examination, including a breast exam, and possibly imaging tests such as a mammogram or ultrasound. Additionally, blood tests might be needed to check your prolactin levels and assess for any underlying hormonal issues. Please consult with a specialist soon to address this issue promptly.

history.doctor:
Based on your symptoms and the information provided, it seems that your mild asthma might be exacerbated due to the physical stress of labor. The shortness of breath with a sensation of blockage could be an asthma exacerbation. However, given the context of labor, we also need to consider other potential obstetric causes such as amniotic fluid aspiration or even anxiety during labor.

I recommend immediate medical attention at the birthing center or hospital where you can be monitored closely for both maternal and fetal well-being. Your healthcare team may administer additional bronchodilators if needed and ensure optimal oxygen saturation levels. They will also assess your progress in labor and decide on the best course of action regarding delivery plans.

Please keep me updated on any changes in your condition, and do not hesitate to ask questions or express concerns to your attending medical personnel.

history.doctor: You're very welcome. It's always better to err on the side of caution, especially in this situation. Your safety and your baby's well-being are top priorities. Stay calm and take deep breaths as much as possible, and know that help is on the way.
history.patient: Doctor, I appreciate your guidance and the steps you've outlined for me to take. However, I would like to request more specific instructions regarding what I should do upon arrival at the birthing center. Should I request any specific tests or monitoring from the healthcare team? Also, if my condition worsens on the way, is there a particular action I should take immediately? Your detailed advice would be very helpful for me to act promptly and ensure the best care for both myself and my baby. Thank you.

history.doctor:
Absolutely, upon arrival at the birthing center, inform the triage nurse or midwife about your symptoms and that you've been experiencing mild shortness of breath with a sensation of blockage in your airways during labor. Mention your history of asthma and that it might be exacerbated due to the stress of labor. They will likely do the following:

1. **Vital Signs Check**: They will check your blood pressure, pulse, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation levels.
2. **Pulmonary Assessment**: You may undergo a lung examination to listen for any wheezing or decreased breath sounds.
3. **Cardiotocography (CTG)**: To monitor the baby's heart rate and assess fetal well-being.
4. **Oxygen Therapy**: If your oxygen saturation is low, they might provide you with supplemental oxygen through a nasal cannula or mask.
5. **Bronchodilator Treatment**: Depending on the severity of your symptoms, they may administer an inhaled bronchodilator treatment to alleviate your breathing difficulties.

If your condition worsens while en route to the birthing center:
- Try to remain calm and focus on taking slow, deep breaths.
- If possible, have someone call the birthing center to let them know your situation has deteriorated so that they can prepare for your arrival.
- If you have a rescue inhaler prescribed for your asthma, use it as directed.
- If you're having severe difficulty breathing, call emergency services immediately (if you haven't already done so) and request an ambulance. 

Remember, clear communication with your healthcare providers is key. They are there to help and ensure the best outcome for both you and your baby. Stay in close contact with them throughout the process, and don't hesitate to express any concerns or changes in your condition.

history.doctor:
Certainly, I'd be happy to provide more guidance. 

To reduce your salt intake:
1. Avoid processed and canned foods as they often contain high levels of sodium.
2. Cook meals at home using fresh ingredients so you can control the amount of salt added. Aim for a daily sodium intake of less than 2300 milligrams, or ideally, no more than 1500 milligrams if you have hypertension.
3. Instead of salt, use herbs, spices, and lemon juice to flavor your food.
4. Check food labels and choose low-sodium options when available.

Regarding maintaining fluid balance:
- It's important not to overhydrate or underhydrate. A general guideline is to drink enough water so that your urine is light yellow or clear throughout the day. However, specific fluid intake requirements can vary based on individual circumstances, so it's best to consult with me or your healthcare provider for personalized advice.

For managing ankle swelling:
- Elevate your legs above heart level whenever possible, especially during rest periods. Ideally, elevate them for about 15-30 minutes, three to four times a day. You can do this by placing a pillow under your feet while lying down or sitting.
- Avoid standing or sitting for prolonged periods without breaks, as this can worsen swelling.

Remember, these are temporary measures to manage symptoms until we get a clearer understanding of the underlying cause through the diagnostic tests. After we receive the results, we can adjust your treatment plan accordingly.

Additionally, regular exercise, meditation, or relaxation techniques may also help manage your anxiety levels.

Given the nature of your symptoms and their onset following the traumatic event, it's crucial to address both the psychological and physical aspects. To proceed with a more accurate diagnosis, I would recommend scheduling some tests. In the meantime, ensure you stay hydrated, get enough rest, and maintain a balanced diet. If your cough worsens or you develop other symptoms, please let me know immediately.

raw_data.question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of a low-grade fever, cough, and runny nose. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination findings are consistent with a diagnosis of a common cold. The physician refers to a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial that evaluated the effectiveness of a new drug for the treatment of the common cold. The mean time for resolution of symptoms for patients receiving the new drug was 6.4 days, compared with a mean time of 6.7 days for patients receiving the placebo (p=0.04). Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of these study results?
raw_data.answer: The findings are clinically insignificant but statistically significant

options.A: The findings are clinically and statistically significant
options.B: The findings are clinically insignificant but statistically significant
options.C: The findings are clinically significant but statistically insignificant
options.D: The findings are neither clinically nor statistically significant

question: Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of these study results?

history.doctor:
For your fever, you can take acetaminophen (e.g., Tylenol) or ibuprofen (e.g., Advil). The usual adult dose for acetaminophen is 325-650mg every 4-6 hours, not exceeding 3000mg in a 24-hour period. For ibuprofen, the typical adult dose is 200-400mg every 4-6 hours, not exceeding 1200mg in a day. Always follow the instructions on the packaging and consult with a pharmacist if you have any questions about dosage or if you're taking other medications.

Regarding the cough and runny nose, over-the-counter antihistamines like loratadine (Claritin) or cetirizine (Zyrtec) could help alleviate your symptoms. Decongestants like pseudoephedrine (Sudafed) can also be used to relieve nasal congestion. However, please note that these may have potential side effects or interactions, so it's best to consult with a pharmacist before use.

For the COVID-19 test, PCR (polymerase chain reaction) tests are considered the gold standard for diagnosing active infection due to their high accuracy. Rapid antigen tests can also be an option but may be less sensitive. You can usually get tested at a local testing site, community health center, or hospital. Some pharmacies and clinics now offer drive-through or walk-in testing as well. Check with your local health department for guidance on where to find a testing location near you.

Remember to call ahead and check their requirements and procedures, as they may differ depending on the facility. Wear a mask when going for the test and maintain social distancing.

Please keep me updated on your progress and let me know if there are any changes in your symptoms or condition after starting the medication. Stay safe and healthy!

raw_data.question: A 27-year-old nurse comes to the emergency department because of nervousness, dizziness, palpitations, and excess perspiration for the past 3 hours. She has had similar episodes over the past 6 months. The symptoms improve following ingestion of orange juice or soft drinks. She says that she has had a great deal of stress. She has been drinking two alcoholic beverages daily for the past month; before this time, she seldom drank alcohol. Examination shows no abnormalities. Her serum glucose concentration is 30 mg/dL.
